Haiti Earthquake Relief | website = OnePatient-Global Health Initiative [http://www.onepatient.org] | footnotes = }} '''Daniel Anthony Ivankovich''' [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]] (b. 1963) is an American [[orthopedics|orthopedic]] [[surgeon]], humanitarian, media personality and [[blues]] musician with the Chicago Blues All-Stars. He is from [[Chicago, Illinois]] where he is known for his advocacy on behalf of the under-served in Chicago's inner city via The Bone Squad.{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-03-07/news/ct-x-0307-trice-column-20120307_1_medicaid-patient-care-health-care|title=Clinic sees people, not dollar signs|publisher=Chicago Tribune|author=Dawn Turner Trice|date=March 7, 2012|accessdate=November 19, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newschannel5.com/story/15474909/seven-foot-surgeon-helps-the-needy|title=Seven-Foot Surgeon Helps The Needy|publisher=News Channel 5|author=|date=September 15, 2011|accessdate=November 19, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.beckersspine.com/orthopedic-spine-industry-leaders/item/2765-orthopedic-and-spine-industry-leader-to-know-dr-daniel-ivankovich-of-chicagos-the-bone-squad|title=Orthopedic and Spine Industry Leader to Know: Dr. Daniel Ivankovich of Chicago's The Bone Squad|publisher=Becker's Spine Review|author=Laura Miller|date=December 23, 2010|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} He is medical director and co-founder of OnePatient - Global Health Initiative, a non-profit foundation created “to treat patients...who have musculoskeletal health disorders, regardless of their ability to pay.”{{cite web|url=http://www.northwestern.edu/magazine/winter2011/feature/bigger-than-life.html|title=Bigger Than Life|publisher=Northwestern Magazine|author=Barbara Mahany|date=|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} OnePatient is based in Chicago, Illinois. ==Early history== Ivankovich was born in [[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]] on November 23, 1963. His family defected from the former [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] to [[Chicago, Illinois]] in 1965.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/January-2011/Chicagoans-of-the-Year-2010-Daniel-Ivankovich/|title=Chicagoans of the Year 2010: Daniel Ivankovich, The Bone Squad|publisher=Chicago Magazine|author=Esther Kang|date=December 22, 2010|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} ==Basketball career== Daniel Ivankovich was an All-State and All-American prep basketball player out of [[Glenbrook South High School]] in 1981.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/espn/story/_/id/7035620/former-basketball-star-mike-williams-begins-walking-again-being-paralyzed-bullet-espn-magazine/|title=Nobody walks alone|publisher=ESPN|author=Brandon Sneed|date=October 12, 2011|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} During his senior year, Ivankovich was invited to the [[Chicago Sun-Times|Chicago Sun-Times’]] all-area travel team. He represented Chicago in the Boston Shootout, a streetball invitational tournament, in 1981. During the tournament he suffered a career-ending injury during an on-court collision. Ivankovich received athletic scholarship offers from 500 colleges, and attended [[Northwestern University]]. He retired from basketball following his freshman year. ==Medical training== Ivankovich was accepted into [[Northwestern University|Northwestern University’s]] Honors Program in Medical Education in 1981. He received his [[doctor of medicine]] from Northwestern University’s [[Feinberg School of Medicine]] in 1995. His postgraduate training in orthopedic surgery was completed at [[Rush University Medical Center]], [[John H. Stroger, Jr. Hospital of Cook County]] (formerly known as Cook County Hospital), and [[Shriner's Hospitals for Children]] in Chicago.{{cite web|url=http://ryortho.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/09_21_10_Newsletter.pdf|title=This Week Orthopedics|publisher=Ry Publications|accessdate=November 19, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/03/03/eveningnews/main6263610.shtml/|title= Chicago Doc Administers Tall Dose of Heart|publisher=CBS News|author=Cynthia Bowers|date=March 3, 2010|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} Ivankovich completed additional fellowship training in adult joint reconstruction. His research emphasis was osteonecrosis and hip replacement in medically co-morbid populations.{{cite news|author=Ivankovich DA|author2=Rosenberg AG|author3=Malamis A.|title=Reconstructive options for osteonecrosis of the femoral head.|publisher=Techniques in Orthopaedics.|year=2001|volume=16|pages=66–79}} He also completed additional fellowship training in reconstructive spine and traumatology at [[Northwestern Memorial Hospital]] and spinal cord rehabilitation at the [[Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago]]. ==Radio career== From 1981 to 1987, Ivankovich worked as a radio announcer, production engineer, and graduate advisor at [[WNUR-FM]] in [[Evanston, Illinois]]. He produced several shows at the CMJ-awarded station, most notably, “Out of the Blue” featuring Chicago blues music, performances, and interviews. The show was picked up by KOST Broadcasting for syndication and ran in over sixty markets from 1985 to 1987. Ivankovich also worked as an announcer and producer for [[WCKG]], the top-rated rock music station in the Chicago market.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotalentmag.com/emag/story/chicago-slim|title=Chicago Slim|publisher=Chicago Talent Magazine|date=May 1, 2012|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} While there, he met [[Stephanie Miller]] who was, at that time, the morning host at WCKG. When Stephanie Miller went to New York to do mornings at WQHT, Ivankovich partnered with her and produced the Hot 97 Morning Show with Stephanie Miller and Howard Hoffman. Ivankovich has subsequently appeared as a guest host on Miller’s talk and music shows. ==Medical career== [[File:Dan Ivankovich tending Haitian boy's tibia fracture.jpg|left|thumb|225px|Dr. Dan Ivankovich, tending to a young Haitian boy's tibia fracture in the aftermath of the 2010 earthquake.]] Ivankovich is an [[orthopedics|orthopedic surgeon]] best known for caring for patients regardless of their ability to pay or insurance status. He is leader of The Bone Squad, "a consortium of surgeons, primary-care doctors, and other medical professionals who treat the city’s low-income population.” After the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]], Ivankovich and his team airlifted thousands of tons of medical supplies to [[Port-au-Prince]].{{cite web|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2010/10/19/local-surgeon-to-be-honored-for-work-in-haiti/|title=Local Surgeon To Be Honored For Work In Haiti|publisher=CBS Chicago|author=|date=October 19, 2010|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} He collaborated with [[Team Rubicon|Team Rubicon USA]] to set up mobile Forward-Assist Surgical Teams (F.A.S.T.) to manage hundreds of Haitians with severe injuries. While rounding through the multiple tent-city medical camps, he and colleagues from [[Handicap International]] discovered nearly fifty patients with severe spinal cord injuries. Ivankovich came upon two such patients, Bazelais Suy and Josette Delisca, who managed to survive despite life-threatening injuries.{{cite web|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?section=news/local&id=7244143|title=2 injured Haitians treated in Chicago|publisher=ABC Chicago|author=Michelle Gallardo|date=January 28, 2010|accessdate=November 19, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2010/sep/7/haiti-quake-survivor-returns-home-after-6-months/?page=all#pagebreak|title=Haiti quake survivor returns home after 6 months|publisher=Washington Times|author=Lindsey Tanner|date=September 7, 2010|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} With the assistance of [[AirMed International]] and MedEvac, Ivankovich personally escorted Suy and Delisca to Chicago, where they received care at [[Northwestern Memorial Hospital]] and the [[Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago]].{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-01-28/news/ct-met-trice-haiti-0129-20100128_1_suy-bazelais-josette-delisca-bazelais-and-delisca|title=Surgeon helps Haiti quake victims defy odds|publisher=Chicago Tribune|author=Dawn Turner Trice|date=January 28, 2010|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} For his work during the aftermath of the Haitian earthquake, Ivankovich was named one of Chicago Magazine’s Chicagoans of the year for 2010 and [[National Association of Social Workers]] Chicago Chapter’s 2010 Public Citizen of the Year.{{cite web|url=http://haitiancongress.org/crisis-relief/dr-dan-ivankovich-bone-squad-bazelais-suys-recovery|title=Dr. Dan Ivankovich, Bone Squad, & Bazelais Suy's Recovery|publisher=Haitian Congress|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} In 2010, Ivankovich was featured on the [[CBS Evening News]] with [[Katie Couric]] in a segment called "The American Spirit". After his appearance on the CBS Evening News, Ivankovich was contacted by [[Mike Williams (basketball)|”Massive” Mike Williams]], former power forward for the [[Atlanta Hawks]], who had been shot and paralyzed while working security at an [[Atlanta]] night club in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-12-06/news/ct-met-trice-bodyguard-1206-20101206_1_spinal-cord-injury-suy-bazelais-chicago-orthopedic-surgeon|title=Ex-NBA player relearns to walk with help from friend|publisher=Chicago Tribune|author=Dawn Turner Trice|date=December 6, 2010|accessdate=November 19, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wbez.org/episode-segments/former-nba-player-fights-paralysis-old-chicago-teammate-his-side|title=Former NBA player fights paralysis with an old Chicago teammate by his side|publisher=WBEZ|author=|date=December 17, 2010|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} Williams remembered Ivankovich from their high school years in Chicago, when both were All-State & All-American basketball players. Williams asked Ivankovich for help in receiving treatment for his injuries. Ivankovich agreed to treat Williams. Williams subsequently regained limited use of his legs.{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/id/41640589/ns/today-today_people/#.UnK27vmsiSo|title=Robot legs may reunite teammates on basketball court|publisher=Today|author=Bob Dotson|date=February 21, 2011|accessdate=November 19, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2010/12/30/doctor-seeks-bionic-legs-for-ex-nba-player/|title=Doctor Seeks Bionic Legs For Ex-NBA Player|publisher=CBS Chicago|author=|date=December 30, 2010|accessdate=November 19, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sfltimes.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=6169/|title=Tragedy And A Dream Reunite Ex-Basketball Buddies|publisher=South Florida Times|author=Lindsey Tanner|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} Ivankovich and Williams partnered with [[Berkeley Bionics]] to fit Williams with eLegs, electronic prostheses. In 2013, Ivankovich won a wrongful termination settlement from the Cook County Health and Hospitals System (CCHHS).{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-04-18/news/ct-met-cook-county-preckwinkle-0418-20130418_1_preckwinkle-county-hospital-system-provident-hospital|title=Cook County to pay $2.6 million to 3 fired doctors|publisher=Chicago Tribune|author=John Byrne|date=April 18, 2013|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} In 2007, Ivankovich, who had been employed as an orthopedic surgeon by Provident Hospital of Cook County from 2002-2007, had made public statements that were critical of proposed budget cuts at the hospital.{{cite web|url=http://www.courthousenews.com/2012/07/23/48625.htm|title=Chicago Doctors May Press Free-Speech Claim|publisher=Courthouse News Service|author=Lorraine Bailey|date=|accessdate=November 19, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.beckershospitalreview.com/legal-regulatory-issues/cook-county-in-illinois-to-pay-26m-to-3-fired-physicians.html|title=Cook County in Illinois to Pay $2.6M to 3 Fired Physicians|publisher=Becker's Hospital Review|author=Molly Gamble|date=April 19, 2013|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} He also supported organizing activities by a physician’s union. Along with two other doctors, Ivankovich was laid off in April 2007 in a reduction of labor resulting from budget cuts.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiercehealthcare.com/story/cook-county-settles-physician-lawsuits-26m/2013-04-19|title=Cook County settles physician lawsuits for $2.6M|publisher=Fierce Healthcare|author=Ron Shinkman|date=April 19, 2013|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} Ivankovich filed suit against the hospital for wrongful termination and alleged the hospital had terminated his employment due to his critical statements and union activity. CCHHS agreed to an out-of-court settlement with Ivankovich and the two other doctors in April 2013. ==Musical career== [[File:Reverend Doctor D in Chicago.jpg|thumb|250px|Reverend Doctor D (Daniel Ivankovich) in Chicago.]] Daniel Ivankovich and his musical partner, "Killer" Ray Allison, are founding members, principal instrumentalists and vocalists for the Chicago Blues All-Stars.{{cite web|url=http://www.americanbluesscene.com/2011/04/doctor-dan-ivankovich-big-bluesman-bigger-heart/|title=Doctor Dan Ivankovich – Big Bluesman, Bigger Heart|publisher=American Blues Scene Magazine|author=Matt Marshall|date=April 6, 2011|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} In 2010, "Killer" Ray Allison, Ivankovich's long-time collaborator, was inducted in the Blues Hall of Fame, as a Great Master Blues Artist. Ivankovich has played alongside myriad Chicago blues and rock musicians such as [[Chuck Berry]], [[James Cotton]], [[Bo Diddley]], [[Buddy Guy]], [[Homesick James]], [[Magic Slim]], [[Hubert Sumlin]], [[Eddie Taylor]] and [[Junior Wells]]. He also had a stint as bandleader for [[Otis Rush]]. Ivankovich also performs and records as a solo artist under the name Chicago Slim.{{cite web|url=http://www.carparelliguitars.com/index.php/endorsees/107-daniel-ivankovich-chicago-blues-all-stars|title=Daniel Ivankovich - Chicago BLUES ALL-STARS|publisher=Carparelli Guitars|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} In 2013, the Chicago Blues All-Stars released Red Hot & Blue.{{cite web|url=http://www.americanbluesscene.com/2013/07/chicago-blues-all-stars-are-red-hot-blue/|title=Chicago Blues All-Stars Are "Red, Hot & Blue"|publisher=American Blues Scene Magazine|author=Barry Kerzner|date=July 11, 2013|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} Ivankovich is also a guitar historian and ethnomusicologist who specializes in guitars made in Chicago, Illinois.{{cite web|url=http://www.premierguitar.com/articles/19828-the-guitars-that-chicago-built|title=24 Windy City Gems|publisher=Premier Guitar|author=Chris McMahon|date=October 17, 2013|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} He is endorsed by Carparelli Guitars and GHS Strings.{{cite web|url=http://www.ghsstrings.com/artists/chicago-blues-all-stars|title=CHICAGO BLUES ALL-STARS|publisher=ghs strings|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} ==Personal life== Ivankovich’s father, Anthony D. Ivankovich MD, is a “renowned” anesthesiologist, former military doctor and Chairman Emeritus of the Department of Anesthesia at [[Rush University]].{{cite news|publisher=Crain's Business Chicago|author=Mike Colias|date=November 9, 2009|title=ONE-MAN SAFETY NET; Robin Hood of poor hospitals treats patients few others will}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rushanesthesia.com/site/aboutus/|title=Rush Department of Anesthesiology|publisher=Rush Anesthesia|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} His mother, Olga Ivankovich MD, is the Clinical Director of the [[Rush University]] Pain Center and a primary care doctor.{{cite web|url=http://www.universitypaincenters.com/Dev2/index.php/clinical-staff-submenu/81-clinical-staff-olga-ivankovich-md|title=Olga Ivankovich, MD|publisher=University Pain Centers|accessdate=November 19, 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.aol.com/video/the-charitable-seven-foot-surgeon-helps-the-needy/517203506/ The Charitable Seven Foot Surgeon Helps The Needy] *[http://vimeo.com/12396710 Dr. Dan Ivankovich -- Distinguished Alumnus (2010)] *[http://www.onepatient.org OnePatient - Global Health Initiative] *[http://www.bonesquad.com The Bone Squad] *[http://www.bluesallstars.com Chicago Blues All-Stars] *[http://reverenddoctord.com Reverend Doctor D - Blog] {{Persondata | NAME = Ivankovich, Daniel | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American orthopedic surgeon | DATE OF BIRTH = 1963 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Zagreb, Croatia | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ivankovich, Daniel}} [[Category:People from Chicago, Illinois]] [[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:American people of Croatian descent]] [[Category:Orthopedic surgeons]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1963 births]]
